This diversity of uses and meanings, combined with the complexity of the feelings involved, makes love unusually difficult to consistently define, even compared to other emotional states.
 
This diversity of uses and meanings, combined with the complexity of the feelings involved, makes love unusually difficult to consistently define, even compared to other emotional states.
    −
[[Humanistic psychology]] sets healthy [[self-esteem]], understood as unconditional self-respect and self-confidence (and interpretable in certain context as self-love), as an essential requirement for every healthy interpersonal relation, including interpersonal love.<ref>Nathaniel Branden. ''The psychology of self-esteem: a new concept of man's psychological nature''. 1981.</ref>
+
[[Humanistic psychology]] sets healthy [[self-esteem]], understood as unconditional self-respect and self-confidence (and interpretable in certain context as self-love), as an essential requirement for every healthy interpersonal relationship, including interpersonal love.<ref>Nathaniel Branden. ''The psychology of self-esteem: a new concept of man's psychological nature''. 1981.</ref>
     
[[Buddhism]] sets attachment as a negative emotion that releases other negative emotions like anger and desire. In the buddhist philosophy, true love is compassionate love.<ref name="Buddha">[http://books.google.es/books?id=VECepVHTH0QC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false Guatama Buddha. ''The Dhammapada''. Translated by Irving Babbitt.]</ref> This concept is diametrically opposed to the concept of capitalism, which promotes the so called inherent selfishness of the human being: for unconditional love there is nothing to trade with.
